advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT (APRIL 1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <http://www.classiccmp.org/dunfield/miscpm/" target="_blank">Dave Dunfield</a> for the picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, JULY 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote>Nice advert, although a little excessive.<p class="petitgris">Byte Magazine</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHARLIE CHAPLIN #7 </strong></font><br><blockquote>TopView, one of the first serious multitasking tool for the IBM PC.<p class="petitgris">Byte Magazine, July 1985</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MAGAZINE COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Gridcase made the cover of SVM (french magazine) in january 1985</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">You know about computers. In fact, you probably own one now. One that you might be thinking of expanding. We have a better idea. Take a giant step into the personal computing future with an amazing, new C4P from Ohio Scientific...<br><br> ...The C4P is an outstanding premium computer - years ahead of the market. We know because there's nothing quite like it for the price, anywhere. And probably won't be for a very long time.</font> <br><br> About the DISPLAY paragraph:<font color="#666666"><br> "256 x 512 effective graphic points"<br><br></font> <b>Kurt Vogel</b> rectifies:<font color="#666666"><br> The C4P did NOT have a 256x512 graphics mode! If it had, that would have been amazing for the price way back then. Instead, it had a 32x64 character display and claimed that because each character was made up of a 8x8 grid that that was supposed to count as 256x512 graphics. Even given that they used an extended 8 bit character set that included special line and shape characters, you were NEVER able to address indivual pixels!</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT (JUNE 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Goupils invade Paris area"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, SEPTEMBER 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Tony Mattson for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> I LEARN AT SCHOOL</strong></font><br><blockquote>French advert for the new model, dated april 1986. <br><br> "I learn at school, I rock at home"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH (STUPID) PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Family life scene in front of a complete Atmos system carefully lined up on the coffee table in the living room, with a minimum of visible cables. <br><br> The flaw?... No, it is not that it is rather difficult to use such a serious configuration for hours sitting on the floor. The flaw comes rather from the photographer who forgot to do the housework before taking the picture and left to posterity his accessories cartons right behind the low dresser.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Teleplay advert for the Teleng Colourstars<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.geocities.com/doubledragon0uk//Home.html" target="_blank">Double Dragon Retro Mess</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> M-SERIES BROCHURE - PAGE 4</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT </strong></font><br><blockquote>One of the first advert for the Atari 520ST checked against an Apple Mac and an Apricot computer. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Bradley Sturch</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZELAND AD. (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> The renaissance machine is a "one-of-a-kind" system for the "one-of-a-kind" person who demands and will not settle for anything less than, the best.</font><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zeland</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> £149 IN JUNE 1981</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1983) </strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br><font color="#666666"> What makes the QX-10 the most remarkably usable computer to date is a unique software system called VALDOC...<br><br> ... VALDOCS may be all the software you will never need. Right out of the box, it's a sophisticated <i>word processor</i>; an <i>information indexer</i> for easy acces to files; an <i>electronic mail system</i>;a <i>calculator</i>;an <i>apointment book</i> and <i>notepad</i>; and a <i>high resolution business graph drawing system</i>...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #1 (1977)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first Apple II advert.<br><br> Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Clear the kitchen table. Bring in the color TV. Plug in your new Apple ll and connect any standard cassette recorder / player. Now, you're ready for an evening of discovery in the new world of personal computers.<br> Only Apple ll makes it that easy. At $1298, it includes video graphics in 15 colors, 8KB ROM and 4KB RAM... It's the first personal computer with a fast version of BASIC permanently stored in ROM...<br><br> Apple ll is also available in board-only form to the do-it-yourself hobbyist. Has all of the features of the Apple ll system but does not include case, keyboard, power supply or game paddles. $598</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RADIOLA ADVERT. 3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.builtInGames: One double sided 3.5'' disk drive (1,4 MB)
computer.description:
The Macintosh SE/30 was the successor to the Apple Macintosh SE and the Macintosh Plus. It ran under Mac OS 6.0.3 or A/UX (Apple?s Unix variant).
Apple had been naming all computers using the 68030 processers with an "x", such as the IIx and IIcx. When it came time to put the 68030 processor into the SE series, they prudently decided that calling it the Macintosh "SEx" wasn't the best marketing idea, so they settled on "SE 30".
Except for the 68030, one of its main differences with the old Mac SE was its separate video RAM (64 KB which could be accessed without slowing down CPU access to the RAM). Its sound system was a limited version of the Apple II GS sound system.
Although the SE-30 had a gray-scale monitor, the onboard video actually supported color. The cost of incorporating a 9" color CRT would have made the machine far too pricey, resulting in the the grayscale CRT. However, the idea of a color CRT would be taken up again with the Colour Classic. The SE-30 also had an expansion slot that could support a variety of 3rd party cards, an example being a combination 10BaseT Ethernet / color video out card. _______________________

emulator.description: Demonstration version of a commercial software (MS DOS & Win95)
emulator.name: Executor

emulator.description: A commercial Software which emulates the Atari ST/TT and the Mac 128/Plus/2 (Win95 / Win NT)
emulator.name: Gemulator

emulator.description: Same as Apple lisa emulator for unix but ported to windows
emulator.name: LisaEm

emulator.description: PearPC is an architecture-independent PowerPC platform emulator capable of running most PowerPC operating systems.
emulator.name: PearPC

emulator.description: Demo version of a commercial software (Linux / NextStep)
emulator.name: Executor
vMac - The Virtual Macintosh Emulator Project

emulator.description: Basilisk II is an Open Source 68k Macintosh emulator. Good emulator, runs on several platforms, even Amiga
emulator.name: Basilisk II

emulator.description: Mini vMac, a spin off of the program vMac, emulates a Macintosh Plus and Macintosh SE. So far it works on Macintosh OS, Microsoft Windows, and the X Window System.
emulator.name: Mini vMac

computer.name: MACINTOSH SE 30
computer.ports: two serial RS232/422 ports; two ADB ports (keyboard, mouse), Stereo, Floppy disk connector, SCSI, 68030 Processor Direct Slot (to connect graphic cards, or network card)
computer.ram: 1 / 4 MB (up to 128 MB) + 256 bytes of PRAM
